Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Engineered Materials for Tissue Engineering and Drug Delivery

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This three year renewal of a Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site from the Jacobs School of Engineering at the University of California-San Diego will focus on the expanding research strength in biomaterials across engineering departments and expose students to biomaterials research with a focus on applications in tissue engineering and drug delivery. This Site will provide lower-division, undergraduate students from traditionally underrepresented groups, with limited research opportunities, with a hands-on biomaterials research experience, faculty and near-peer mentoring, research presentations at local and national meetings, and professional development activities that encourage continued graduate training in biomaterials.

Over a three year period, this REU program will engage undergraduate students in a 10-week intensive, summer research experience focused on the generation of new biomaterials knowledge made possible through access to state-of-the-art facilities at UCSD, cutting-edge research projects, and accomplished faculty mentors. A "boot camp" will be conducted during the first week of the program to ensure that all participants have the necessary basic skills required to succeed in their research experience. Community building, professional development activities, weekly research skills workshops, a biomaterials-based REU journal club, and attendance and participation in research conferences and professional meetings are components of this REU Site and will result in better-trained undergraduate students who are highly motivated to pursue graduate training in biomaterials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The REU site "Engineered Materials for Tissue Engineering and Drug Delivery" at UC San Diego focused on impacting and transforming the lives of its participants through a residential summer research experience augmented by activities that were designed to encourage their entry into graduate school upon completion of their degrees. This site specific targeted lower-division undergraduates (i.e. freshmen and sophomores) with the hypothesis that earlier interventions with programs that encourage graduate school preparation and train participants in research will positively impact career trajectories and enrollment in graduate education. The site is also targeted at participants from traditionally under-represented groups in bioengineering, especially under-represented minorities and (to a lesser extent) women. From 2016 to 2018, 20 of the 29 participants were lower-division students and 25 of 29 were minorities and/or women. We found that 11 of 17 participants that have finished their undergraduate studies to date have enrolled in graduate school (65%). Of this cohort, 8 of 11 under-represented participants that have graduated from college are enrolled in graduate school (72%); this is nearly 10-fold higher than the national average for under-represented. With our focus on lower-division students, we also found that their academic performance post-REU program remains on track with their peers at UC San Diego and may even be better during the transition to junior year (increase of 0.17 GPA points) when many difficult engineering courses often begin. Of the program elements that may have contributed to this success, participants rated their graduate and postdoctoral mentors most highly as well as specific elements of the training, including weekly workshops and a "boot camp" intended to bring participants with limited research experience up-to-speed on basic laboratory techniques used in the manufacture and application of biomaterials. Local and national presentations of participant research, both orally in front of colleagues and via poster presentation, were also highly cited by participants as building their confidence to succed in graduate school, their future careers, and beyond.
